creator: info@orangexl.com
text:
Currently, setting up subdomains on Apache is not simple or easy. 
You could put in ServerAlias (subdomain|*).domain.com, but you still need to 
ReWrite URL's later to a their respective dirs (or not, but what would be the 
use then). 

Why not create an (Alias|DocumentRoot)-directive for these case's?
SubdomainAlias email /email/ (points email.domain.com to DocumentRoot/email/)

This allows a clear, easy and comfortable way to set up subdomains. Please also 
note that the first method which is currently being used is broken (bug 12155)

creator: slive@apache.org
text: I think you are looking for mod_vhost_alias.

No. You could use mod_vhost_alias, but it is not easy to set up if you don't 
want all your vhost confs to be the same, or if you would like to point 
webmail.domain.com to /webmail/ and all other (any.domain.com) to / . 
If you can do this, than I would suggest to change the documentation for 
mod_vhost_alias.
creator: info@orangexl.com

text:
There are three ways to do what you want in Apache:

1. Name virtual-hosts.

2. mod_vhost_alias.

3. mod_rewrite.

Between the three of them, you can do pretty much anything.  What you are
requesting is not at all a well-defined configuration directive.  The specific
configuration you are looking for can be easily implimented simply by
adding another <VirtualHost> section with the appropriate ServerName and
DocumentRoot.
